citations.narrative:
The facility's inventory records did not include disposition information for a budgie that died on October 13, 2024.
Acquisition and disposition records are necessary to accurately track and identify animals used for regulated purposes,
and to help assess the animal care program. The licensee must ensure all required records are kept and maintained for
all animals acquired, transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed. The records shall include any offspring born or
hatched while in the facility’s possession.
Acquisition records shall include:
• the date the animal was acquired
• the species of the animal
• the name and address of the person from whom the animal was acquired
• the USDA license or registration number of the person from whom the animal was acquired if those individuals are
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if
they are not licensed under the Act
• the number of animals in the shipment.
Disposition records shall include:
• the date the animal was sold or died
• the species of the animal
• If sold or given: the name and address of the person to whom the animal was sold or given
• If sold or given: the USDA license or registration number of the person to whom the animal was sold or given if they are
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if
they are not licensed under the Act
• the number of animals in the shipment.
The facility must maintain a record of acquisitions and dispositions for all regulated animals and ensure all required
information is properly and accurately documented at all times.
Correct by December 18, 2024

The capybara enclosure is not maintained in good repair to protect the animal from injury. A heat lamp’s unprotected
electrical cord in the capybara’s enclosure is hanging approximately two feet above the floor. The heat lamp is for a
tortoise also housed in the enclosure and is powered. While the light itself is protected from the capybara, the light’s
electrical cord is hanging within reach of the capybara, risking chewing or pulling
Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals that may bite or pull on them. Unprotected electrical cords that
are within an animal's enclosure allows access to an electrical hazard that can cause electrocution, injury and/or death.
Housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect animals from injury including limiting access to electrical
cords.
Corrected at time of inspection. Correct by December 17, 2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has not developed, documented, and followed a species-specific plan for the environmental enhancement of
individually housed birds that are unable to see and hear other birds. A budgie has been individually housed in a cage in
the office for observation since November 20, 2024. This budgie is not able to see or hear other birds. Budgies are a
social species of birds and require special consideration when housed without being able to see and hear birds of their
own or compatible species. The facility’s written environmental enhancement plan (EEP) does not have information in
their written EEP for this special consideration, nor was one implemented for this bird. Without such environmental
enhancement, this bird may develop abnormal behaviors and could experience psychological distress.
The facility must develop, document, and implement an adequate enrichment plan per the attending veterinarian’s
instructions for all their birds, including special attention regarding enhancement of the environment of those individually
housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of their own or compatible species.
Correct by: December 24, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
MARGARET SHAVER, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility's inventory records did not include disposition information for a budgie that died on October 13, 2024. 
Acquisition and disposition records are necessary to accurately track and identify animals used for regulated purposes, 
and to help assess the animal care program. The licensee must ensure all required records are kept and maintained for 
all animals acquired, transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed. The records shall include any offspring born or 
hatched while in the facility’s possession.  
 
Acquisition records shall include: 
• the date the animal was acquired 
• the species of the animal 
•  the name and address of the person from whom the animal was acquired  
• the USDA license or registration number of the person from whom the animal was acquired if those individuals are 
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if 
they are not licensed under the Act 
•  the number of animals in the shipment.  
 
Disposition records shall include:  
• the date the animal was sold or died 
• the species of the animal 
•  If sold or given: the name and address of the person to whom the animal was sold or given  
• If sold or given: the USDA license or registration number of the person to whom the animal was sold or given if they are 
licensed under the Act, OR the vehicle license number and state and the driver's license number and state of the person if 
they are not licensed under the Act 
• the number of animals in the shipment. 
 
The facility must maintain a record of acquisitions and dispositions for all regulated animals and ensure all required 
information is properly and accurately documented at all times.  
 
Correct by December 18, 2024

3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The capybara enclosure is not maintained in good repair to protect the animal from injury. A heat lamp’s unprotected 
electrical cord in the capybara’s enclosure is hanging approximately two feet above the floor. The heat lamp is for a 
tortoise also housed in the enclosure and is powered. While the light itself is protected from the capybara, the light’s 
electrical cord is hanging within reach of the capybara, risking chewing or pulling 
 
Electrical cords pose a significant health risk to animals that may bite or pull on them. Unprotected electrical cords that 
are within an animal's enclosure allows access to an electrical hazard that can cause electrocution, injury and/or death. 
Housing facilities shall be maintained in good repair to protect animals from injury including limiting access to electrical 
cords. 
 
Corrected at time of inspection. Correct by December 17, 2024 
3.154(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility has not developed, documented, and followed a species-specific plan for the environmental enhancement of 
individually housed birds that are unable to see and hear other birds. A budgie has been individually housed in a cage in 
the office for observation since November 20, 2024. This budgie is not able to see or hear other birds. Budgies are a 
social species of birds and require special consideration when housed without being able to see and hear birds of their 
own or compatible species. The facility’s written environmental enhancement plan (EEP) does not have information in 
their written EEP for this special consideration, nor was one implemented for this bird. Without such environmental 
enhancement, this bird may develop abnormal behaviors and could experience psychological distress. 
 
The facility must develop, document, and implement an adequate enrichment plan per the attending veterinarian’s 
instructions for all their birds, including special attention regarding enhancement of the environment of those individually 
housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of their own or compatible species. 
 
Correct by: December 24, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MARGARET SHAVER, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG

species.scientific: Ara, Anodorhynchus, Primolius, Diopsittaca spp hybrid
